title: Agentic AI
text:
Welcome
Welcome to this hands-on guide to setting up your environment and connecting to SQL Server databases using Python.
What you will achieve:

Prepare your operating system and developer tools.
Install the Microsoft SQL Server ODBC drivers and command-line utilities.
Configure VS Code so you can browse databases and run scripts comfortably.
Use Python, SQLAlchemy, and pandas to connect, query, and explore data.







Along the way you will learn why each tool matters, how to verify every step, and where to look when something goes wrong.

title: 2  Microsoft SQL Server
text:
2.1 What It Is
Microsoft SQL Server is a relational database management system (RDBMS) developed by Microsoft. It stores data in structured tables, enforces transactional integrity, and provides a rich set of services for analytics, reporting, and integration.
The platform runs on Windows and Linux, supports on-premises and cloud deployments, and scales from lightweight edge workloads to large enterprise data warehouses.

title: 2  Microsoft SQL Server
text:
Relational database engine: Implements the ANSI SQL standard with T-SQL extensions, transactional isolation levels, and ACID compliance.
Comprehensive data platform: Bundles services for business intelligence (SQL Server Analysis Services), data movement (SQL Server Integration Services), and reporting (SQL Server Reporting Services).
Managed platform options: Powers Azure SQL offerings, including Azure SQL Database, Azure SQL Managed Instance, and SQL Server on Azure Virtual Machines.

title: 2  Microsoft SQL Server
text:
2.2 Typical Use Cases

Line-of-business applications that require strong transactional consistency (e.g., ERP, CRM, finance).
Analytical workloads such as data marts and enterprise data warehouses.
Hybrid architectures combining operational databases with near-real-time analytics through features such as In-Memory OLTP and columnstore indexes.
Data integration scenarios where SQL Server acts as a hub for ingesting, transforming, and serving data to downstream systems.

title: 3  AdventureWorks
text:
3.1 What We’ll Build with AdventureWorks
We use the AdventureWorks sample database from Microsoft as our primary dataset.
The AdventureWorks database is a realistic, relational dataset that models a mid-sized manufacturing and sales company called Adventure Works Cycles.
It contains data about products, sales, customers, employees, vendors, and production processes, making it ideal for demonstrating complete, data-driven application pipelines.
In this course, the dataset acts as the shared backend for a collection of interactive AI-powered applications. All apps connect to a Microsoft SQL Server instance that hosts the AdventureWorks data.
We use the dataset to explore the full AI + data workflow — from SQL querying to intelligent front-end delivery.
Example applications include:

All participants will receive API keys and connection credentials to access the shared AdventureWorks database.
These keys provide secure, authenticated access from the different front-end applications.

title: 4  Prepare Your Machine
text:
4.1 Windows users
Before installing anything, make sure your operating system and accounts are ready. A few minutes of preparation will prevent mysterious permission errors later.

title: 4  Prepare Your Machine
text:
4.1.1 Basic requirements

Check for updates

On Windows, open Settings > Windows Update.

Developer mode

Open Windows Settings.
Go to Update & Security > For developers.
Toggle Developer Mode and accept the disclaimer. This unlocks features used by Git Bash and command-line installers.




4.1.2 Command-line basics
We use Git Bash as our terminal. Download the latest Git for Windows installer from git-scm.com and complete the setup (Git Bash is included). After installation, open Git Bash from the Start menu.






Why Git Bash?





Git Bash provides a Unix-like terminal experience on Windows, making it easier to follow along with commands that are commonly used in macOS and Linux environments.



Keep the terminal window open while you work through the chapters.



4.1.3 uv
We use uv, a strictly written Python package manager that is extremely fast. It replaces pip, poetry, and virtualenv.
To install uv on Windows, run this command in your terminal (PowerShell):
powershell -ExecutionPolicy ByPass -c "irm https://astral.sh/uv/install.ps1 | iex"
Restart your terminal after installation to ensure uv is recognized.

title: 4  Prepare Your Machine
text:
4.2 Mac users

4.2.1 Basic requirements
Check for updates: On macOS, open System Settings > General > Software Update.


4.2.2 Command-line basics
Launch Terminal (Spotlight search for “Terminal”). Commands in this book assume the zsh shell, which is the default on modern macOS systems.
Keep the terminal window open while you work through the chapters.


4.2.3 Package manager
Homebrew downloads applications, command line tools, and libraries with one command. You avoid manual downloads and it keeps everything organized.
Install Homebrew:

Open Terminal and run the official installer:
/bin/bash -c "$(curl -fsSL https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Homebrew/install/HEAD/install.sh)"
Enter your password when prompted (you won’t see any characters while typing).
Press RETURN/ENTER to continue
When the script finishes, follow the on-screen instructions to add Homebrew to your shell profile (this step is required for brew to be found).
Close the Terminal window.
Open a new Terminal, then verify the installation:
brew --version
Make sure everything is up to date:
brew update
Use brew upgrade to actually update installed packages.
brew upgrade



4.2.4 uv
We use uv, a strictly written Python package manager that is extremely fast. It replaces pip, poetry, and virtualenv.
To install uv on macOS, run this command in your terminal:
curl -LsSf https://astral.sh/uv/install.sh | sh
Restart your terminal after installation.

title: 5  Server Tools for macOS
text:
5.1 Prerequisites
This chapter walks through installing the Microsoft SQL Server ODBC driver and command-line utilities on macOS. Apple Silicon (M1/M2/…) and Intel Macs use the same commands—Homebrew handles the architecture details for you.
You need to have Homebrew installed. If you haven’t set it up yet, follow the instructions on their website.

title: 5  Server Tools for macOS
section: 5.2 Install the Microsoft tap and drivers
text:
5.2 Install the Microsoft tap and drivers
Microsoft publishes their macOS packages via a dedicated Homebrew tap. Add it and install the required formulas. Open your Terminal and run:
brew tap microsoft/mssql-release https://github.com/Microsoft/homebrew-mssql-release
ACCEPT_EULA=Y brew install msodbcsql18 mssql-tools unixodbc

msodbcsql18 is the latest Microsoft ODBC Driver for SQL Server.
mssql-tools installs sqlcmd and bcp for command-line access.
unixodbc provides the shared ODBC libraries Python will load.







The ACCEPT_EULA=Y prefix lets the installer know you accept the Microsoft end-user license agreement. Without it the install stops halfway through.

title: 5  Server Tools for macOS
section: 5.3 Add tools to your PATH (if needed)
text:
5.3 Add tools to your PATH (if needed)
Some shells require an extra step to expose the SQL Server utilities. Add the following line to ~/.zshrc or ~/.bash_profile if sqlcmd is not found after reopening Terminal:
export PATH="/opt/homebrew/opt/msodbcsql18/bin:/opt/homebrew/opt/mssql-tools/bin:$PATH"
Intel Macs should use /usr/local/opt/ instead of /opt/homebrew/opt/.
Reload your shell:
source ~/.zshrc

title: 5  Server Tools for macOS
text:
5.4 Test the installation
Confirm that the ODBC driver registered correctly:
odbcinst -j
Look for lines referencing Driver Manager: unixODBC.
Your Mac is now ready to connect to SQL Server databases from VS Code and Python.

title: 5  Server Tools for macOS
text:

title: 7  Configure VS Code
text:
7.1 Install VS Code
Visual Studio Code acts as your code editor, terminal, and database explorer. This chapter covers the essential extensions and workspace settings for SQL Server work.
If you haven’t already, install Visual Studio Code:
Launch VS Code once to allow it to finish installing components.

title: 7  Configure VS Code
text:
macOS: Download the from code.visualstudio.com and drag Visual Studio Code into Applications.
Windows: Download the installer and click through the setup, leaving the default options enabled (add to PATH, register the code command, etc.).

title: 7  Configure VS Code
text:
7.2 Essential extensions
Open the Extensions view and install:

Python (ms-python.python) – language support and linting.
SQL Server (mssql) (ms-mssql.mssql) – database connections and query runner.
vscode-icons (vscode-icons-team.vscode-icons) – file icons for better visual identification.

title: 7  Configure VS Code
text:
7.3 Enable the code command

7.3.1 macOS Terminal

Launch VS Code, press Cmd+Shift+P, and run Shell Command: Install ‘code’ command in PATH.
Close any open Terminal windows, then open a new one and run
code --version
to confirm the CLI is available.
From the folder you want to open, run
code .
to launch VS Code in that location.



7.3.2 Windows (Git Bash)

Run
code --version
in Git Bash; if it works, you’re done.
If the command is missing, add VS Code’s bin directory to your Git Bash PATH by appending the snippet below to ~/.bashrc (create the file if it doesn’t exist):
VS_CODE="/c/Users/$USERNAME/AppData/Local/Programs/Microsoft VS Code/bin"
if [ -d "$VS_CODE" ] && [[ ":$PATH:" != *":$VS_CODE:"* ]]; then
  PATH="$VS_CODE:$PATH"
fi
Reload Git Bash
source ~/.bashrc

Or open a new window and run
code --version
Again. Once it prints a version number,
code . 
will open VS Code from that folder.

title: 7  Configure VS Code
text:
7.4 Integrated terminal tips

Open the integrated terminal in VS Code. On Windows, set Git Bash as the default shell so every VS Code terminal matches the rest of this guide.
Set your default terminal profile via Terminal > Configure Default Profile… so that VS Code opens the same shell you used during installation.

title: 8  Create a SQL Server Connection
text:
8.1 Create a connection profile
Use the SQL Server (mssql) extension in VS Code to connect, save, and reuse profiles for SQL Server or Azure SQL databases. The steps below walk through creating your first connection and include tips for common authentication modes.
crumbs: 8  Create a SQL Server Connection

title: 8  Create a SQL Server Connection
text:
In VS Code, open the SQL Server view (activity bar icon with the SQL badge).
Select Add Connection (➕ icon). The Connect to Database dialog matches the screenshot and uses the following fields:

Profile Name – friendly label that shows up under SQL Server ▶ Connections.
Connection Group – optional folder for organizing profiles. Leave <Default>.
Input type

Use Parameters (default): exposes the individual fields listed below.

Server name – Use the named instance provided by your instructor.
Trust server certificate – enable this field.
Authentication type – select SQL Login
User name / Password – enter the credentials provided by your instructor.
Save Password – stores credentials securely in your OS keychain.
Database name – enter the name provided by your instructor..
Encrypt – pick Optional.
Advanced – not necessary for this connection.

After filling the required fields (marked with *), click Connect. When prompted, save the profile. Saving makes it appear in the SQL Server panel so you can double-click it later; declining runs a one-off connection only.
crumbs: 8  Create a SQL Server Connection

title: 8  Create a SQL Server Connection
text:
8.2 Verify the connection

In your VS Code Extensions, open the SQL Server view if not already visible.
In the CONNECTIONS window, move your mouse to the name of your database, right-click and choose New Query.
Type a simple check such as:

SELECT TOP (3)
ID_Product,
Material_Description,
Product_Category,
Transfer_Price_EUR
FROM dbo.Dim_Product
ORDER BY ID_Product;

Press F5 or click the Run symbol (▶️) in the editor toolbar (at the top right of the script).
The Results grid should return the products ordered by ID_Product. If VS Code prompts again for credentials, re-enter them and retry.
If you encounter connection issues, double-check the server name, authentication type, and credentials. Review any error messages for clues.

title: 10  SQL Example Script
text:
10.1 What the script does
This chapter walks through sql_example.py, a self-contained example that connects to SQL Server, runs a sample query, and prints the results with pandas. Use it as a template for your own analytics scripts once the database connection is working.
The script demonstrates an end-to-end query workflow:
Always execute the script through your managed environment:
uv run guarantees that the dependencies defined in pyproject.toml are loaded. Once the connection works, you can reuse the structure for your own queries.

title: 10  SQL Example Script
text:
loads the required libraries (dotenv, sqlalchemy, pandas) and environment variables
builds a secure connection string from the .env values
creates an engine with SQLAlchemy and verifies the database connection
runs a sample query and prints the first rows of a table


uv run python sql_example.py

title: 10  SQL Example Script
text:
10.2 Step by step

10.2.1 1. Load libraries and parse the .env
import os
import urllib.parse
import pandas as pd
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from sqlalchemy import create_engine, text

load_dotenv()
load_dotenv() reads the connection parameters from the .env file so credentials stay out of the source code. If any of the required values (server, database, username, password) are missing, the script aborts with a clear error message—double-check the .env file first.


10.2.2 2. Prepare connection parameters
SERVER = os.getenv("MSSQL_SERVER")
DATABASE = os.getenv("MSSQL_DATABASE")
USERNAME = os.getenv("MSSQL_USERNAME")
PASSWORD = os.getenv("MSSQL_PASSWORD")
DRIVER = os.getenv("MSSQL_DRIVER", "ODBC Driver 18 for SQL Server")
TRUST_CERT = os.getenv("TRUST_SERVER_CERTIFICATE", "false").lower() == "true"

params = urllib.parse.quote_plus(
    f"DRIVER={{{DRIVER}}};"
    f"SERVER={SERVER};"
    f"DATABASE={DATABASE};"
    f"UID={USERNAME};"
    f"PWD={PASSWORD};"
    f"TrustServerCertificate={'Yes' if TRUST_CERT else 'No'};"
)

urllib.parse.quote_plus escapes special characters in the password so the ODBC driver accepts the connection string.
The TrustServerCertificate flag is controlled via the .env variable TRUST_SERVER_CERTIFICATE and defaults to off.



10.2.3 3. Create the engine and test the connection
engine = create_engine(f"mssql+pyodbc:///?odbc_connect={params}")

with engine.connect() as connection:
    version = connection.execute(text("SELECT @@VERSION AS version"))
    print("Connection successful!")
    print("SQL Server version:", version.scalar())
The engine manages the connection pool. The with block ensures the session closes properly after the query. The initial SELECT @@VERSION confirms that connectivity works and prints the SQL Server version that responded.


10.2.4 4. Sample query with pandas
SAMPLE_QUERY = text(
    """
    SELECT TOP (10)
           ID_Product,
           Material_Description,
           Product_Category,
           Transfer_Price_EUR
    FROM dbo.Dim_Product
    ORDER BY ID_Product;
    """
)

df = pd.read_sql(SAMPLE_QUERY, connection)
print("\nSample data:")
print(df)
pd.read_sql combines SQLAlchemy and pandas so you get a DataFrame directly. The call runs inside the same with block as the version query, meaning the connection closes automatically. Modify the SQL statement to match tables you can access. The goal is to see the data quickly without exporting to CSV first.

title: 10  SQL Example Script
text:
10.3 Adapt it to your projects

Explore new tables: Adjust the selected columns and the FROM clause to inspect other datasets.
Add additional checks: Chain multiple text() statements to run sanity checks in sequence.
Persist results: Append df.to_csv(...) or df.to_parquet(...) if you want to store query outputs for later.

Keep the structure modular: one function that returns the engine, another for common queries, and dedicated modules for heavier analytics. That approach keeps the code testable and reusable in notebooks, ETL jobs, or dashboards.

title: 1  Introduction
section: 1.2 The Project: Multimodal SQL Analyst Agent
text:
1.2 The Project: Multimodal SQL Analyst Agent
You will act as AI consultants for Global Bike Inc. (GBI), a world-class bicycle manufacturer. Your mission is to build an intelligent AI agent that empowers GBI’s employees to get answers from their data instantly.

1.2.1 The Challenge
GBI has a lot of data in their SQL Server, but accessing it requires technical skills. Business users want to ask questions in plain English (or even by voice!) and get immediate answers.


1.2.2 Your Solution
You will build a Multimodal SQL Analyst Agent that can:

Listen & Understand: Accept questions via text or voice.
Write Code: Automatically generate safe and correct SQL queries.
Analyze: Execute the query on GBI’s database.
Explain & Visualize: Present the results with a clear text explanation and a beautiful chart.

Technologies we will use:

Python: The primary programming language.
Google Gemini: For the intelligence (LLM).
Gradio: To build the user interface.

title: 1  Introduction
text:
1.3 Getting Started
To be ready for our first session, please ensure you have the following:

Google Account: You will need this to access Google’s AI tools.
Laptop: Bring your own device.
Software Setup: Please complete the steps in the Prepare Your Machine section before class. This includes installing Python and setting up your development environment.

We look forward to building the future of analytics with you!

title: 4  Prepare Your Machine
text:
4.3 Google API Key
To use Google’s AI models (Gemini), you need an API key.

Get your key: Go to Google AI Studio and click Create API key.
Copy the key: Copy the generated key string.
Secure your key:

Create a new file in your project folder named .env.
Open the file and add the following line, replacing YOUR_KEY with your actual key:

GOOGLE_API_KEY=AIzaSy...

Important: Never share this key or commit the .env file to public repositories (GitHub, etc.).
